Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. Rachael Rollins to join national push for reconciliation commission to confront racismSuffolk District Attorney Rachael Rollins is joining a national pilot program to create truth, justice, and reconciliation commissions -- inspired in part by post-apartheid work in South Africa -- to explore misconduct by police officers and prosecutors.

A 2015 audit of the BPD turned up various issues with the department’s overtime system. Were any of them corrected? There have been no significant changes to the department’s overtime policy since a 2015 audit. What’s more, as national protests over police killings of unarmed Black people have turned a sharp eye toward police spending, overtime pay at the police department has continued to balloon.

A 2015 audit of the BPD turned up various issues with the department’s overtime system. Were any of them corrected? There have been no significant changes to the department’s overtime policy since a 2015 audit. What’s more, as national protests over police killings of unarmed Black people have turned a sharp eye toward police spending, overtime pay at the police department has continued to balloon.

Hodgepodge of rules stymie those seeking coronavirus tests to meet vacation requirementsNew Maine guidelines mandate that out-of-state visitors (except those from New Hampshire and Vermont, and now New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut) quarantine for 14 days upon arrival or show proof of a negative COVID-19 test conducted no longer than 72 hours before arrival. That requirement has stymied many Massachusetts residents, who say they’ve encountered a baffling array of rules among different testing sites, making it challenging to get timely results.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

Rachael Rollins to join national push for reconciliation commission to confront racismSuffolk District Attorney Rachael Rollins is joining a national pilot program to create truth, justice, and reconciliation commissions -- inspired in part by post-apartheid work in South Africa -- to explore misconduct by police officers and prosecutors.

Boston police once resembled the community. But force has grown whiter as city becomes more diverse  The Boston Police Department has failed to keep up with the shifting demographics of the city. Despite pledges from Mayor Martin J. Walsh to diversify the city’s workforce, the police department has become slightly more white as the city’s population has become less so.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

Boston police once resembled the community. But force has grown whiter as city becomes more diverse  The Boston Police Department has failed to keep up with the shifting demographics of the city. Despite pledges from Mayor Martin J. Walsh to diversify the city’s workforce, the police department has become slightly more white as the city’s population has become less so.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.
